div.p: (Music)

>>Intro: Hi. This video introduces the
Fix the Web Project
through its founder Doctor Gail Bradbrook of Citizens Online,

and a supporter and user of the
serivce Mandy De la Mare
who is chair of the Thalidomide Trust.
(Music)

>>Gail Bradbrook: Fix the Web is an
innovative project from Citizens Online
and is set up to address web accessibility.

The internet can be hugely liberating
for disabled people.

It can help to overcome prejudice,
it offers new way to communicate.
But actually web technologies and software
are repeating the mistakes of the built environment.

So what we've done is make it really easy
for disabled people to report issues.

In under sixty seconds they can tell us
what's bothering them.
They can do it in several ways, they can fill out a form on the website.
They can use Twitter or email to contact us,
or they can actually use a downloadable toolbar.

>>Mandy De la Mare: The kind of problems
I experience on the internet are:
filling in forms, social networking,

chat rooms, downloading music
or anything from downloading sites,
anything where you've got photographs or graphics
that clash with the screen reader
would make it fall over.

>>Gail: I really felt that the Nominet Trust
were brave in funding this project

because to start off with we didn't have
a clear agenda forward.

The funding really enabled us to
have a period of stakeholder dialogue

with people like the British Computer Society
and Nomensa and AbilityNet,

and also disabled people to really
get to the heart of the issue.
>>Mandy: As individuals you don't get listened to. You can send emails to the companies.

You can write to the companies but when it
comes to actually doing anything
they don't ever bother.
But hopefully, something like Fix the Web
which will be known nationally, then they might take more notice of that.
>>Gail: What we're aiming for with Fix the Web is having at least ten thousand volunteers on hand
to deal with web accessibility issues.
And with sufficient disabled people reporting
we could process a quarter of a million websites in the space of a couple of years,

and I really think that would
make a big impact.
(End Music)
